answers.text: usefulness of the canals was short-lived, though some have now been restored for recreation

qas.question: What was built int the 19th century

answers.text: 19th century also saw the construction of railways to and through Somerset

qas.question: How many railways served the county

answers.text: The county was served by five pre-1923 Grouping railway companies

qas.question: Were any of the railways  electrified

answers.text: None of these lines, in Somerset, are electrified.

qas.question: What railways lines are still in use today

answers.text: The former main lines of the GWR are still in use today, although many of its branch lines were scrapped under the notorious Beeching Axe

qas.question: Where does the Great Western Railway go to from Somerset?
In what year was the Beeching Axe?
In what year was the Dorset Joint Railway closed?
Which of these lines are electrified outside of Somerset?
Who now owns the West Somerset Railway?

context: The <a0_0>usefulness of the canals was short-lived, though some have now been restored for recreation<a0_0/>. The <a1_0>19th century also saw the construction of railways to and through Somerset<a1_0/>. <a2_0>The county was served by five pre-<b6_0><b7_0>1923<b7_0/><b6_0/> <b9_0>Grouping railway companies<b9_0/><a2_0/>: the Great Western Railway (GWR); a branch of the Midland Railway (MR) to Bath Green Park (and another one to Bristol); the Somerset and Dorset Joint Railway, and the <b5_0>London<b5_0/> and South Western Railway (L&SWR). <a4_0>The former main lines of the GWR are still in use today, although many of its branch lines were scrapped under the notorious Beeching Axe<a4_0/>. The former lines of the Somerset and Dorset Joint Railway closed completely, as has the branch of the Midland Railway to Bath Green Park (and to Bristol St Philips); however, the L&SWR survived as a part of the present <b8_0>West of England Main Line<b8_0/>. <a3_0>None of these lines, in Somerset, are electrified.<a3_0/> Two branch lines, the West and East Somerset Railways, were rescued and transferred back to private ownership as "heritage" lines. The fifth railway was a short-lived light railway, the Weston, Clevedon and Portishead Light Railway. The West Somerset Mineral Railway carried the iron ore from the Brendon Hills to Watchet.
